t: Job 41
“Can*pn you pull in Leviathan with a fishhook or*ld tie down its tongue with a rope?
Can*ln you put a cord through its nose or*ld pierce its jaw with a hook?
Will*ln it keep begging you for mercy? Will*ld it speak to you with gentle words?
Will*ln it make an agreement with you for*ld you to take it as your slave for life?
Can*ln you make a pet of it like a bird or*ld put it on a leash for the young women in your house?
Will*ln traders barter for it? Will*ld they divide it up among the merchants?
Can*ln you fill its hide with harpoons or*ld its head with fishing spears?
If*ln you lay a hand on it, you*ld will remember the struggle and never do it again!
Any*ln hope of subduing it is false; the*ld mere sight of it is overpowering.
No*ln one is fierce enough to rouse it. Who*ld then is able to stand against me?
Who*ln has a claim against me that I must pay? Everything*ld under heaven belongs to me.
“I*pn will not fail to speak of Leviathan’s limbs, its*ld strength and its graceful form.
Who*ln can strip off its outer coat? Who*ld can penetrate its double coat of armor?
Who*ln dares open the doors of its mouth, ringed*ld about with fearsome teeth?
Its*ln back has rows of shields tightly*ld sealed together;
each*ln is so close to the next that*ld no air can pass between.
They*ln are joined fast to one another; they*ld cling together and cannot be parted.
Its*ln snorting throws out flashes of light; its*ld eyes are like the rays of dawn.
Flames*ln stream from its mouth; sparks*ld of fire shoot out.
Smoke*ln pours from its nostrils as*ld from a boiling pot over burning reeds.
Its*ln breath sets coals ablaze, and*ld flames dart from its mouth.
Strength*ln resides in its neck; dismay*ld goes before it.
The*ln folds of its flesh are tightly joined; they*ld are firm and immovable.
Its*ln chest is hard as rock, hard*ld as a lower millstone.
When*ln it rises up, the mighty are terrified; they*ld retreat before its thrashing.
The*ln sword that reaches it has no effect, nor*ld does the spear or the dart or the javelin.
Iron*ln it treats like straw and*ld bronze like rotten wood.
Arrows*ln do not make it flee; slingstones*ld are like chaff to it.
A*ln club seems to it but a piece of straw; it*ld laughs at the rattling of the lance.
Its*ln undersides are jagged potsherds, leaving*ld a trail in the mud like a threshing sledge.
It*ln makes the depths churn like a boiling caldron and*ld stirs up the sea like a pot of ointment.
It*ln leaves a glistening wake behind it; one*ld would think the deep had white hair.
Nothing*ln on earth is its equal— a*ld creature without fear.
It*ln looks down on all that are haughty; it*ld is king over all that are proud.”
